title: How to Enable Function Keys via Your Keyboard or Computer Settings

steps.title: Hold down the Fn key.
steps.content: Hold down the Fn key. This key is usually found in the bottom-left corner of your keyboard next to the Ctrl or Control key. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If you're using a full-size Mac keyboard, you may find it between the letter keys and the 10-key numeric keypad. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Hit the function key you wish to use.
steps.content: Hit the function key you wish to use. These are found at the top of your keyboard. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Try pressing F1 while in an application. If this opens a help menu, you successfully enabled the function key. On a Mac, this key generally lowers the volume.

steps.title: Turn on the F lock key.
steps.content: Turn on the F lock key. If your keyboard has this key, it'll usually be found in the top-left or top-right corner. A light will usually turn on when the key is enabled. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Press the function key you wish to use.
steps.content: Press the function key you wish to use. These are at the top of the keyboard. Try pressing F1 while in an application to check that you have successfully enabled the function keys. In Windows, this usually opens the Help menu. On a Mac, it turns down the volume. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Access your BIOS/UEFI.
steps.content: Access your BIOS/UEFI. The BIOS (Basic Input/Output System), also called a UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface), is software built into your computer that gives it instructions on how to do various things. If your function keys are not working, they may be disabled in your BIOS/UEFI. [6] X Research source You must press a button during startup (before the Windows logo appears) to enter the BIOS/UEFI, but the button differs depending on your computer. Common buttons to press are F1, F2, F10, F12, Del, or Esc.

steps.title: Find the configuration menu.
steps.content: Find the configuration menu. This may be found in different locations depending on your computer manufacturer, and may be a submenu under an "Advanced" menu. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Locate an option that says "hotkey" or "Fn Key."
steps.content: Locate an option that says "hotkey" or "Fn Key." Again, the exact wording will vary depending on your computer manufacturer.

steps.title: Enable the "hotkey"/"Fn Key" menu option.
steps.content: Enable the "hotkey"/"Fn Key" menu option. If you see that this option is already enabled, then the BIOS/UEFI is not responsible for your function keys not working as intended. [8] X Research source
